title: CERTAINTY
subtitle: It must have been her
explanation: Use 'must have' when you are certain something happened (positive deduction). Use 'can't have' or 'couldn't have' when you are certain something did NOT happen (negative deduction). Based on evidence or logic.
structure: must have + past participle / can't have + past participle

examples.before: The lights are off. I'm certain <<they left>>.
examples.after: The lights are off. **<<They must have left>>**.

examples.before: Her coat is here. I'm sure <<she arrived>>.
examples.after: Her coat is here. **<<She must have arrived>>**.

examples.before: The door is locked. Obviously <<someone locked>> it.
examples.after: The door is locked. **<<Someone must have locked>>** it.

examples.before: He knows everything. Clearly <<he heard>> about it.
examples.after: He knows everything. **<<He must have heard>>** about it.

examples.before: She's exhausted. I'm certain <<she worked>> all night.
examples.after: She's exhausted. **<<She must have worked>>** all night.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Negative Deduction (can't have / couldn't have)

examples.before: He's never been abroad. It's impossible <<he visited>> Paris.
examples.after: He's never been abroad. **<<He can't have visited>>** Paris.

examples.before: She doesn't speak Spanish. There's no way <<she understood>> them.
examples.after: She doesn't speak Spanish. **<<She can't have understood>>** them.

examples.before: The shop was closed. It's impossible <<they bought>> anything.
examples.after: The shop was closed. **<<They couldn't have bought>>** anything.

examples.before: He was in London. There's no way <<he saw>> me in Paris.
examples.after: He was in London. **<<He couldn't have seen>>** me in Paris.

examples.before: She left before I arrived. It's impossible <<she took>> my keys.
examples.after: She left before I arrived. **<<She can't have taken>>** my keys.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Mixed Certainty (must have / can't have)

examples.before: The grass is wet. I'm certain <<it rained>> last night.
examples.after: The grass is wet. **<<It must have rained>>** last night.

examples.before: He has my phone. There's no way <<I lost>> it.
examples.after: He has my phone. **<<I can't have lost>>** it.

examples.before: She's crying. Clearly <<someone upset>> her.
examples.after: She's crying. **<<Someone must have upset>>** her.

examples.before: The house is empty. It's impossible <<anyone stayed>> there.
examples.after: The house is empty. **<<Anyone couldn't have stayed>>** there.

examples.before: He knows the answer. Obviously <<he studied>> for the test.
examples.after: He knows the answer. **<<He must have studied>>** for the test.

title: PROBABILITY
subtitle: She might have forgotten
explanation: Use 'may have', 'might have', or 'could have' to express possibility about the past when you're not certain. These modals suggest something was possible, but you don't know for sure. 'May have' ‚âà 50%, 'might have' ‚âà 40%, 'could have' = general possibility.
structure: may have / might have / could have + past participle

examples.before: Perhaps <<she missed>> the train.
examples.after: **<<She may have missed>>** the train.

examples.before: Maybe <<they forgot>> about the meeting.
examples.after: **<<They may have forgotten>>** about the meeting.

examples.before: It's possible <<he went>> home early.
examples.after: **<<He may have gone>>** home early.

examples.before: Perhaps <<someone took>> my umbrella by mistake.
examples.after: **<<Someone may have taken>>** my umbrella by mistake.

examples.before: Maybe <<the letter arrived>> yesterday.
examples.after: **<<The letter may have arrived>>** yesterday.

examples.before: Perhaps <<he lost>> his wallet.
examples.after: **<<He might have lost>>** his wallet.

examples.before: Maybe <<she left>> already.
examples.after: **<<She might have left>>** already.

examples.before: It's possible <<they changed>> their plans.
examples.after: **<<They might have changed>>** their plans.

examples.before: Perhaps <<I made>> a mistake.
examples.after: **<<I might have made>>** a mistake.

examples.before: Maybe <<the bus broke>> down.
examples.after: **<<The bus might have broken>>** down.

examples.before: It's possible <<someone called>> while I was out.
examples.after: **<<Someone could have called>>** while I was out.

examples.before: Perhaps <<the cat knocked>> over the vase.
examples.after: **<<The cat could have knocked>>** over the vase.

examples.before: Maybe <<he forgot>> to lock the door.
examples.after: **<<He could have forgotten>>** to lock the door.

examples.before: It's possible <<they got>> stuck in traffic.
examples.after: **<<They could have got>>** stuck in traffic.

examples.before: Perhaps <<she heard>> the news already.
examples.after: **<<She could have heard>>** the news already.

title: CRITICISM
subtitle: You should have told me
explanation: Use 'should have' / 'ought to have' to criticize past actions or express regret about what didn't happen. It means something was the right thing to do, but it didn't happen. Use 'shouldn't have' for criticism of actions that DID happen but were wrong.
structure: should have / ought to have / shouldn't have + past participle

examples.before: I didn't study. I regret it now.
examples.after: **<<I should have studied>>**.

examples.before: You didn't call her. That was wrong.
examples.after: **<<You should have called>>** her.

examples.before: We didn't book early. Now there are no tickets.
examples.after: **<<We should have booked>>** early.

examples.before: He didn't listen to advice. That was a mistake.
examples.after: **<<He should have listened>>** to advice.

examples.before: They didn't check the weather. Now they're stuck.
examples.after: **<<They should have checked>>** the weather.

examples.before: She didn't tell the truth. That was wrong.
examples.after: **<<She ought to have told>>** the truth.

examples.before: You didn't inform us. That was a mistake.
examples.after: **<<You ought to have informed>>** us.

examples.before: He didn't save money. He regrets it now.
examples.after: **<<He ought to have saved>>** money.

examples.before: We didn't apologize. That was rude.
examples.after: **<<We ought to have apologized>>**.

examples.before: They didn't ask permission. That was inappropriate.
examples.after: **<<They ought to have asked>>** permission.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Shouldn't have (criticism of wrong actions)

examples.before: You told him the secret. That was wrong.
examples.after: **<<You shouldn't have told>>** him the secret.

examples.before: I ate so much. Now I feel sick.
examples.after: **<<I shouldn't have eaten>>** so much.

examples.before: She quit her job. That was a bad decision.
examples.after: **<<She shouldn't have quit>>** her job.

examples.before: They spent all their savings. That was foolish.
examples.after: **<<They shouldn't have spent>>** all their savings.

examples.before: He trusted them. That was naive.
examples.after: **<<He shouldn't have trusted>>** them.

title: CONDITIONAL
subtitle: If I had known, I would have helped
explanation: Use 'would have' for imaginary or hypothetical results in the past. It shows what WOULD have happened if the situation had been different. Always connected to a past condition (usually 'if + past perfect'). This expresses regret or imaginary outcomes.
structure: would have + past participle (+ if + past perfect)

examples.before: I didn't know, so I <<didn't help>>.
examples.after: **If I had known, <<I would have helped>>**.

examples.before: She wasn't invited, so she <<didn't come>>.
examples.after: **If she had been invited, <<she would have come>>**.

examples.before: We didn't have time, so we <<didn't visit>> the museum.
examples.after: **If we had had time, <<we would have visited>>** the museum.

examples.before: He didn't see the sign, so he <<didn't stop>>.
examples.after: **If he had seen the sign, <<he would have stopped>>**.

examples.before: They didn't study, so they <<didn't pass>> the exam.
examples.after: **If they had studied, <<they would have passed>>** the exam.

examples.before: It rained, so we <<didn't go>> to the beach.
examples.after: **If it hadn't rained, <<we would have gone>>** to the beach.

examples.before: I was busy, so I <<didn't call>> you.
examples.after: **If I hadn't been busy, <<I would have called>>** you.

examples.before: She forgot, so she <<didn't bring>> the documents.
examples.after: **If she hadn't forgotten, <<she would have brought>>** the documents.

examples.before: The train was late, so we <<missed>> the connection.
examples.after: **If the train hadn't been late, <<we wouldn't have missed>>** the connection.

examples.before: He lied, so we <<didn't trust>> him.
examples.after: **If he hadn't lied, <<we would have trusted>>** him.

examples.before: She <<worked>> hard, so she <<succeeded>>.
examples.after: **If she hadn't worked hard, <<she wouldn't have succeeded>>**.

examples.before: They <<saved>> money, so they <<bought>> a house.
examples.after: **If they hadn't saved money, <<they wouldn't have bought>>** a house.

examples.before: I <<tried>> harder, so I <<achieved>> my goal.
examples.after: **If I hadn't tried harder, <<I wouldn't have achieved>>** my goal.

examples.before: The weather <<was>> good, so we <<enjoyed>> the trip.
examples.after: **If the weather hadn't been good, <<we wouldn't have enjoyed>>** the trip.

examples.before: He <<listened>> to advice, so he <<avoided>> problems.
examples.after: **If he hadn't listened to advice, <<he wouldn't have avoided>>** problems.

title: ABILITY
subtitle: I could have gone but I didn't
explanation: Use 'could have' to talk about ability or opportunity that existed in the past but wasn't used. It means you had the chance or ability to do something, but you didn't do it. Different from 'could have' for possibility (which expresses uncertainty about whether something happened).

sets.setTitle: Set 1: Unrealized Ability (had the chance but didn't)

examples.before: I was able to go to the party, but I <<didn't go>>.
examples.after: **<<I could have gone>>** to the party, but I didn't.

examples.before: She had the opportunity to study abroad, but she <<didn't take>> it.
examples.after: **<<She could have studied>>** abroad, but she didn't.

examples.before: We were able to win the match, but we <<didn't play>> well.
examples.after: **<<We could have won>>** the match, but we didn't play well.

examples.before: He had the chance to buy the house, but he <<didn't buy>> it.
examples.after: **<<He could have bought>>** the house, but he didn't.

examples.before: They were able to finish early, but they <<didn't finish>>.
examples.after: **<<They could have finished>>** early, but they didn't.

examples.before: I had time to learn Spanish, but I <<didn't learn>> it.
examples.after: **<<I could have learned>>** Spanish, but I didn't.

examples.before: You had the chance to invest, but you <<didn't invest>>.
examples.after: **<<You could have invested>>**, but you didn't.

examples.before: She was free to help us, but she <<didn't help>>.
examples.after: **<<She could have helped>>** us, but she didn't.

examples.before: We had the skills to solve it, but we <<didn't solve>> it.
examples.after: **<<We could have solved>>** it, but we didn't.

examples.before: He had the option to retire early, but he <<didn't retire>>.
examples.after: **<<He could have retired>>** early, but he didn't.

examples.before: With more effort, I was capable of <<achieving>> better results.
examples.after: **<<I could have achieved>>** better results with more effort.

examples.before: With preparation, she was able to <<pass>> the exam.
examples.after: **<<She could have passed>>** the exam with preparation.

examples.before: With your help, we were capable of <<finishing>> on time.
examples.after: **<<We could have finished>>** on time with your help.

examples.before: With planning, they were able to <<avoid>> the problem.
examples.after: **<<They could have avoided>>** the problem with planning.

examples.before: With practice, he was capable of <<becoming>> a champion.
examples.after: **<<He could have become>>** a champion with practice.

title: FUTURE PERFECT
subtitle: They will have finished by tomorrow
explanation: Use 'will have' + past participle to talk about actions that will be completed before a specific time in the future. It connects a future moment with an action that will already be finished by then. Often used with time expressions like 'by', 'before', 'by the time'.

examples.before: They <<will finish>> the project before next week.
examples.after: **<<They will have finished>>** the project by next week.

examples.before: I <<will complete>> my degree before 2026.
examples.after: **<<I will have completed>>** my degree by 2026.

examples.before: She <<will read>> all the books before the exam.
examples.after: **<<She will have read>>** all the books by the exam.

examples.before: We <<will save>> enough money before summer.
examples.after: **<<We will have saved>>** enough money by summer.

examples.before: The builders <<will construct>> the house before Christmas.
examples.after: **<<The builders will have constructed>>** the house by Christmas.

sets.setTitle: Set 2: Future Perfect with 'by the time'

examples.before: I <<will finish>> cooking when you arrive.
examples.after: **<<I will have finished>>** cooking by the time you arrive.

examples.before: They <<will leave>> when we get there.
examples.after: **<<They will have left>>** by the time we get there.

examples.before: She <<will graduate>> when her parents visit.
examples.after: **<<She will have graduated>>** by the time her parents visit.

examples.before: The film <<will end>> when you get home.
examples.after: **<<The film will have ended>>** by the time you get home.

examples.before: He <<will recover>> when his family arrives.
examples.after: **<<He will have recovered>>** by the time his family arrives.

sets.setTitle: Set 3: Future Perfect - Mixed Time References

examples.before: The train <<will depart>> before we reach the station.
examples.after: **<<The train will have departed>>** before we reach the station.

examples.before: I <<will live>> here for ten years next month.
examples.after: **<<I will have lived>>** here for ten years next month.

examples.before: They <<will work>> on this project for six months by April.
examples.after: **<<They will have worked>>** on this project for six months by April.

examples.before: She <<will study>> English for five years by graduation.
examples.after: **<<She will have studied>>** English for five years by graduation.

examples.before: We <<will know>> each other for twenty years next summer.
examples.after: **<<We will have known>>** each other for twenty years next summer.
